I think it is vital to have an option to disable this feature somewhere in the
Tools > Options > Keymap
or
Tools > Options > Editor > Code Completion

It is especially confusing that in the KeyMap we have "Wheel up" and "Wheel down" but we don't have "Right Click" and "Left Click". It looks like overlook to me

I suspect that the nature of this freezing is the overload of 2 features on the same condition "CTRL+hover": 
1) the tooltip window with methods header definition
2) turning a text into a link that leads to the declaration

Thus, I believe the ability of disable each of these features separately would solve the freezing bug

Let me take a step back. So, the LSP server produces `documentSymbols`, and when there's a package-info, the document symbols contain also an entry for the package (with sub-elements), with broken positions. The broken positions then cause the Outline view to not work.

So, we need to do something about the package in the Outline. There are three variants:
 - variant 1: have the package at the same level as top-level classes. Seems this was the behavior at some point in the past, based on my reading of the history.
  - Outline view: ![var1-outline](https://github.com/apache/netbeans/assets/51319204/d91b5424-d351-4d77-9d35-12a0f256f664);
  - breadcrumbs when the caret is in the `main` method: ![var1-breadcrumbs](https://github.com/apache/netbeans/assets/51319204/f7870ad8-4f46-466e-96e5-a2e40a9da451)
 - variant 2: have the package enclose the top-level classes. Would make some sense, but seems to break breadcrumbs. This is actually what the patch in this PR does.
  - Outline view: ![var2-outline](https://github.com/apache/netbeans/assets/51319204/df51c920-de33-438f-bdc5-9f9df6da7e3d)
  - breadcrumbs when caret is in the `main` method: ![var2-breadcrumbs](https://github.com/apache/netbeans/assets/51319204/7c17d154-04ff-43ad-bec2-ac509f88e4d6)
 - variant 3: do not show the package in Outline (this is what basically happens today, if the Outline words)
  - Outline view: ![var3-outline](https://github.com/apache/netbeans/assets/51319204/20585199-c142-4fea-b867-f6fd25ae3a02)
  - breadcrumbs when caret is in the `main` method: ![var3-breadcrumbs](https://github.com/apache/netbeans/assets/51319204/ba61f858-efae-4f0d-91cf-91af1a516d08)

I think variant 2 is disqualified, as it breaks the breadcrumbs. I don't have a strong opinion on decision between variant 1 and variant 3 - I wonder if @dbalek or @MartinBalin have some opinions here.

Regarding how does this affect the IDE - the NetBeans Swing UI is not affected at all, AFAIK. The ASF VS Code extension is affected I think, but has been for quite some time, I believe.

I personally don't see a strong need to push for integrating to NB 20. I personally think this can be "backported" to the Java Platform Support extension if needed.
I'm in favour of not showing package in outline view. Just fix it as Dusan found there is some invalid position sent over LSP when there is package-info.java. Fix this and not push it to 20.

Well, this could work. My only concern is that `mouseButtonKeyCode` is a public API, we shall notify the users in Javadoc about the additional 4,5 virtual buttons for horizontal scrolling on Linux, so people would be aware of that.

Funnily enough, my preference for handling here is partly simplicity, but also because I think it keeps the API as intended.

The mapping of hardware button to OS button to JDK button to NB windows system button is in many ways an implementation detail. In future we could make this change optional or even allow other options in the window system without changing the API.

> Downgrade a JDK is a hack

its no downgrade. JDK 19 is end of life.

> JDK 21 is a Release Candidate just yet.

JDK 21 is released. However, it was released after NetBeans 19 so we couldn't support it at that time.

You can run NB 19 on the latest upgrade releases of following still supported JDKs: 11, 17, 20 as mentioned on the [download page](https://netbeans.apache.org/front/main/download/nb19/).

11 and 17 are long term support releases. NetBeans 20 will also support JDK 21 which is the next long term support release.

There is another situation, that (I believe) is caused by this lack of a way to disable this feature.

`<ctrl> + e` - is a hotkey to delete a line of code, it is a light weight task, but when I press `<ctrl>` it activates the whole caboodle of functions related to mouse position such as - form a tooltip to turn and turning a text into a link.

So it freezes the whole system again for no reason, making combinations like ` (<ctrl> + e)`, ` (<ctrl> + x)`, ` (<ctrl> + c)`, ` (<ctrl> + v)`, ` (<ctrl> + z)`  vey annoying and even useless depending on where you mouse is resting at that moment of time.
Specifically `<ctrl> + e` is more affected then the others because I often do it with my left hand while moving mouse out of the way by my right hand. Or maybe `<ctrl> + e` makes the code to move under the steady mouse courser and the system considers it as a mouse hover.

I vividly remember having this `<ctrl> + e` issue on my previous work, which was more than 5 years ago. 
It means that this issue cannot be fixed by installing older version of Java, version 17 is just 2 years old.
And It also means that this issue is coming from some legacy code. I remember there was a developer version back then that supported php7 and I used it because Netbeans-8 did not support php7.

Well, just tested NetBeans 20-rc3 (I do not think that it would be any different in NetBeans 19), with JDK 21, that Cyrillic alphabet is displayed correctly in NetBeans, on Linux with UTF-8.

Java changed it's default encoding to UTF-8 from JDK-18. The garbage you are seeing are UTF-8 charachters. You can set the default file encoding on windows by adding `-J-Dfile.encoding=UTF-8` to the NetBeans command line arguments.

Windows has a long history using it's own codepages instead of UniCode, so that could be an issue for non-Latin alphabets.

Solution use UniCode, (UTF-8) everywhere.

![image](https://github.com/apache/netbeans/assets/1381701/221872f9-1d2c-4a4a-9fc7-1aabea7421b1)
![image](https://github.com/apache/netbeans/assets/1381701/ca561264-85ef-449d-9ecd-0070d7f28403)

I've took the text from here: https://r12a.github.io/scripts/tutorial/summaries/cyrillic

According to Google Translate it says: "Register now for the Tenth International Unicode Conference"

Looks related to something @lkishalmi brought up a while back on importing window configuration.  There's a `DocumentGroups` folder in `<userdir>/config` that contains the group configuration and window modes, which are copied across, but window settings files (hence document references) that are not.  I'm not sure if it's a good idea to bring those across as is though?

EDIT: I also deleted the `DocumentGroups` folder and restarted NB19, and the group names still showed up, so it might be somewhere else they're stored that is being imported.

Overall, I'm always in support of code cleanup.

I would suggest that in the future you try and keep the changes in the same domain. This will make code review easier.

For example..
1 - If you say I'm going to clean up module XYZ, then it's appropriate to make a bunch of different changes in there.
2 - If you say I'm going to clean up the List generic, then keep the changes to cleaning up JUST the List interface.

It becomes harder for a volunteer like me to do a code review when a bunch of unrelated changes are requested. Doesn't mean the changes aren't useful, it's just harder to read/understand.

Maybe it is better to use a library like https://github.com/commonmark/commonmark-java to render markdown to html and make the preview html viewer? Besides it is possible to add rules.css file, that can be edited by NB user.

Well, so far for whatever reason Markdown files used two `MIME_TYPE`-s `text/x-markdown-nb` and `text/x-markdown` probably that was an oversight from the past days.

That made it possible to add the `Plain text` spellchecking support enabled for these files. it would be good to ignore spell checking in fenced texts, but that obviously needs more work. This addresses #6653
Closing as a duplicate of #3962
@BradWalker accepted
Hi @mbien, Can this feature be planned for the next release?

> Well, so far for whatever reason Markdown files used two `MIME_TYPE`-s `text/x-markdown-nb` and `text/x-markdown` probably that was an oversight from the past days.
> 
> That made it possible to add the `Plain text` spellchecking support enabled for these files. it would be good to ignore spell checking in fenced texts, but that obviously needs more work. This addresses #6653

How is it possible to have 2 different mimetypes for the same file extension?
@jGauravGupta sure but it would need reviews. If you know a committer who is interested in this, feel free to tag. Adding NB21 milestone. (I am not even using windows for anything)

> How is it possible to have 2 different mimetypes for the same file extension?

I think the bug is here: https://github.com/lkishalmi/netbeans/blob/c3dc5eb35cd382ac663db24ea9b79fcc0c725851/ide/markdown/src/org/netbeans/modules/markdown/MarkdownDataObject.java#L112

Where the `DataObject` which is addigned from the Resolver to the MIME `text/x-markdown-nb` registers an editor with the MIME `text/x-markdown`. That's being fixed in this PR.

Let's try to enable tests too.  Working locally.

Had to comment out a few things.  Most were failing in the same place with NB19.  The only extra failing tests with the JGit upgrade in NB20 were related to message format changes.

The most important thing - the cherry pick test failed without the changes here.

Before we make a buggy situation worse by adding complexity, we should fix the problem. What I see is, that there are multiple places in NetBeans that modify the shared stylesheet and that is the problem. There can be an argument for the LAF to modify the global stylesheet, but all other places should use the solution you suggest in the `MarkdownEditorKit`, i.e. override getStylesheet and do their modifications there and then.
So I think #6662 goes into the wrong direction by adding complexity without clean benefits.
